One... El Casper and TWO other men, El Smokey, a teen with crazy eyes and EL BOMBA, a hefty Guatemalan in his late-twentie jump up and begin beating the boy. The men HOLLER as they rush in throwing Mara Salvatrucha (MS13) gang signs (”"M” then “S shapes with their hands) and stacking those with their clica’s name “CONFETI LOCOS” in a form of sign-language. We see a large expanse of the capitol and its foothills. city covered with colorful homes, patches of tropical gre and smog. On the bottom of the frame THREE ADOLESCENT GIRLS make th way up a long set of stairs towards us, sharing a cigaret SAYRA, 15, an olive-skinned girl with long hair and brigh eyes stands between CLARISSA and YAMILA.
You’re so lucky, Sayra. (BEAT)
If my Dad came back to take me north with him...

Pendeja.

I’ll pray for you. Sayra and Clarissa continue on, we linger for a moment on Yamila who sadly watches them walk away. She finishes off the butt and drops it to the ground. We pan away from her to catch up to Sayra and Clarissa as they enter their neighborhood, past vendors, CAT-CALLING who they give the finger and soccer playing children. Sayra and Clarissa climb into the room from a window. The laugh as they fall to the floor--

--landing on a stained mattress, half covered with a worn flower print sheet in a tiny, sparse room with two other similar mattress on the floor. She reacts, shrugging in a “what do y expect?” kind of way.
He’s here. Clarissa trips over a BACKPACK. Sayra quickly stuffs it under a shelf.
Come on. (BEAT)

We have a front door you know. Sayra trips Orlando, sweeping his back leg just as he stumbles into the NEXT ROOM, a compact concrete space tha doubles as a kitchen and a bedroom. The girls try to cont their laughter before entering. Sayra pauses, her mood shifts, she looks nervously at Clarissa. To comfort her, Clarissa presses their foreheads together... The next room -- serious faced Sayra looks around, an old woman, NANA, glares up at her. Lying on a blanket covered couch, her sick eyes guide us to a some seats where Orlan sits down abruptly, next to his pregnant girlfriend, CECI 19, and... HORACIO, mid-thirties. Bushy eye-brows and weathered fac mid-conversation with Nana. He sees Sayra, his eyes redden as he stands, sniffing and wiping his nose gruffly. Sayra stops in the doorway, Clarissa hovers behind her. Horacio opens his arms, gesturing for her to hug him.
If I didn’t know I wouldn’t recognize her. Sayra stays in the doorway, crosses her arms and waits.
Go on. Horacio indicates again he’s waiting for her to hug him.
(trying hard) You're all... like a real woman. She relents, approaches and sticks out her hand, in a cordial, but cold handshake. Horacio reciprocates warily.
She's done nothing but talk about you. Appalled and embarrassed, Sayra retreats.
You'll have lots of time together, now.
I wish Mami, but with Yessenia alone with the kids... we’ll leave tomorrow on the congolén.
So Soon? You can’t stay longer? (to Sayra) You packed?
No.
Then you better get started.
I don’t want to go. This comes as a shock.
The hell you don’t.
I never said I'd go for sure. The entire room breaks into noise.
It’s what’s best.

I don’t want to go with him. Do you want me to leave, Nana? The old woman doesn’t exactly say no, it’s pretty clear s rather the girl left. Sayra looks around the room. The attention and pressure infuriates and hurts her. Sayra walks out of the house. Suddenly Clarissa is left behind, awkwardly, in the room -- she turns and looks at Orlando. EXT. TAPACHULA TRAIN YARD (AKA LA BOMBILLA), MEXICO — DAY The train yard, populated with about 50 CENTRAL AMERICAN IMMIGRANTS, has four tracks and an abandoned passenger platform. El Casper and the boy, now known as SMILEY, sit on the platform. El Casper, visibly bored, watches over the immigrants like a shepherd. Smiley copies Casper whenever adjusts his sitting position. LUCRESIA, a transvestite with boxer shorts hiked up over tight T-shirt and a bucket balanced on her head saunters She has a sassy sense of humor with rapid-fire responses anyone who makes a comment to her. He pulls out the phone. Text messag ONDE STAS? He stuffs the phone back in his pocket, eager seems, to move.  Casper whistles at Lucresia, calling her over.
El Casper and Smiley walk across a metal bridge spanning oily creek filled with garbage. On the other side FOUR kids fish despite the pollution. O of them is drawing an MS13 “X3” on the bridge.
Casper! They jump up and flash the gang’s sign. El Casper kicks o of them in the butt then hurries on.
He starts to climb through the window of a simple looking story house, but stops and turns around to Smiley.
Wait here.
How long? El Lil' Mago said we were supposed to stay in La Bombilla-
-Not long. He climbs into the window.

A 15 year-old girl, MARTHA MARLEN, lies sleeping on a cou Casper admires her peaceful, smooth face, sleepy eyes, sweating beading on her forehead. He gently sits down next to her and leans forward, but be he can kiss her she awakens, laying out a barrage of slap and catching him by surprise.
Stop it! What are you doing? He grabs her flailing hands and forces her back, falling top of her.  10
Get off of me.

You better get off of me or I’1l scream, I swear to God I will. Faking like she’s going to scream, El Casper covers her m with his. They give each other one long wet kiss. MARTHA MARLEN (CONT’D) I still hate you. El Casper reaches around to his back pocket and pulls out nylon flowers. Martha Marlen’s eyes light up. She takes the flowers and pushes El Casper off of her, disappearing into the living room/kitchen. He can hear her fiddling with a bucket of water.
(El Casper yells to her) They don’t need water. She comes back in holding the flowers in the cup.

I know. She sets them down next to her bed. El Casper watches her adoringly. She catches him, smiles, then pulls off his hoodie and shirt all at once. His body is covered in the same tattoos as El Lil' Mago: three points of la vida loca on his hand, a rosary around wrist, “perdoname madre mia” on his neck and over his hea still raw “Martha Marlen.” He hugs her tight, breathing in her scent, then pulls her down to him and rolling on top of her. They kiss again. EXT. MARTHA MARLEN’S HOUSE - DAY 10 Smiley tries to look through the window but can barely ho himself up long enough to see El Casper and Martha Marlen moving sexually on her bed.  11 10. He slips down, he eagerly tries to pull himself back up, is too weak from the baptism. He sits down, disappointed.
Sayra watches the movements of the city from this vantage point. Orlando approaches her from behind. She says nothi to him. He sits down quietly, appreciating the view.
They're going to build a golf course there. (BEAT)
You like golf?
I’ve never played.
Me neither. (BEAT)
I understand why you’d want to do this trip. I’m not sure yet if I understand why I should. (BEAT)
I’ve just gone along, bad shit happens and I just go along with it. Just like your baby and Ceci will have to, with out you.
If you want to stay, Nana won’t force you to go, but...
I don’t care. I don’t need him. I could go north on my own if I wanted to.

Good, then send me money when you get there. You're fifteen Sayra, you really think you could do this on your own? It’s dangerous, you've heard the stories. You need a coyote, you know how much that costs? She shrugs.  12 11.
Come with us. I know it won’t be easy there either, but at least you'll have us. There’s nothing for you here. Nothing. She grinds the ground with her shoes.
If I went, it wouldn’t be for him and it wouldn’t be for you neither. It would be for me. I’d make my own decisions.
Fine.

Alright, then I’1l think about it. You can tell him that. The first sharp BRASS notes of “CANCION MIXTECA” played b ragged brass band key-noted with a MARIMBA echo over the of a river... EXT. SUCHIATE RIVER - GUATEMALA -— DAY 12

Left side SUPER: TECUN UMAN, GUATEMALA Right side SUPER: CIUDAD HIDALGO, MEXICO Nothing more than a brown, 200 yard wide river divides th two countries. We pan down from the landscape to a birds- perspective of the river. The source of the key notes in the music floats onto screen... A MARIMBA (looks like an oversized xylophone) played by TWO MEN on a raft made of intertubes and wooden palettes. FOUR similar rafts float into view. The ones moving right are cramped with people -- the ones moving left, product. BOYS with long poles push the rafts forward. We move towards one of those rafts with people, where everyone except for Sayra stares eagerly at the coming Mexican shore. She stares at the surreal looking MARIMBA raft.  13 14 12. Horacio sits on the front of the raft. His bushy eyebrows drip sweat as he joins Orlando in prayer.

...Amen. Horacio crosses his chest and looks back at his daughter, seems to ignore them both. Their raft wobbles before it hits the shore, she clenches wooden boards, her knuckles whiten. Horacio steps off and turns to help Sayra, but she still sits with her back to them, frozen. He turns and walks away along with Orlando. Sayra notices they aren’t waiting for her. She stands awkwardly and run to join them. EXT. CIUDAD HIDALGO —- CONTINUOUS 13 Sayra catches up to Horacio and Orlando, who stand frozen front of TWO JUDICIAL POLICE OFFICERS.
Welcome to Mexico. Papers? The officers grab the three of them by the neck and force them into a concrete building.

Horacio, we don’t need to act like other fathers and daughters, we don't even need to be friends, okay? We’re adults, as far as I’m concerned, you’re taking me with you, I’m grateful. Orlando throws Horacio the bottle, who pops it open and h it to Sayra.
Here. Lucresia saunters by, announcing her products with a lazy drawl...

9-0-8-5-5-5-0-1-8-7 Then break into laughter together.
I remember him handsomer.  23 25.

It does to me. EXT. EL LIL' MAGO’S BACK PATIO - DUSK Smiley sits by himself. He seems sick and slightly bewildered. El Lil’ Mago sits down next to him, rubbing h neck in a brotherly way.
